abstract.p: Comments on letter from S. O. Glenie [see 6440] concerning the eyes of trumpeting elephants.

div.p: It is extremely kind in you & your friends to take so much trouble about the fowls. If you have not the pure breed the results will of course be doubtful; & I am unwilling to believe that Blyth & Layard were both mistaken. I shd much like to hear whether the males of the black chickens spoken of by Mr Layard, undergo any change when they become adult. I have been very glad to see Mr Glenie’s letter; & shd you have any opportunity I hope you will return to him & to Mr Layard my sincere thanks

I am astonished at what Mr Glenie says about the elephants not contracting the orbicular muscle, for I & others saw this contraction plainly when the elephants trumpeted loudly in the Zool. gardens— Perhaps too great a contraction is expected.
I received some time ago a very interesting & beautiful specimen from you shewing a surprizing difference in the form of the leaves.
With very many thanks for all your kindness | yours very sincerely | Ch. Darwin

div.note: Thwaites’s friends Charles Peter Layard and Samuel Owen Glenie sent CD observations on a variety of Ceylon (Sri Lanka) fowl (see letter to G. H. K. Thwaites, 19 May [1868], letter from C. P. Layard to G. H. K. Thwaites, 28 July 1868, and letter from S. O. Glenie, 27 November 1868).

CD refers to comments by Edward Blyth and Edgar Leopold Layard on the difficulty in finding cocks of the black-skinned (black-boned) fowl found in Ceylon. See letter to G. H. K. Thwaites, 28 September [1868] and n. 3.
In his letter to Thwaites of 28 July 1868, C. P. Layard had reported owning two cocks with characteristics that E. L. Layard considered peculiar to the female bird.
